captions.text: Take a look out your window,
put on your glasses if you wear them.
You might want to grab a pair of binoculars, too,
or a magnifying lens.
Now, what do you see?
Well, whatever it is,
it's not the multiple layers of glass
right in front of you.
But have you ever wondered
how something so solid can be so invisible?
To understand that,
we have to understand what glass actually is,
and where it comes from.
It all begins in the Earth's crust,
where the two most common elements are
silicon and oxygen.
These react together to form silicon dioxide,
whose molecules arrange themselves
into a regular crystalline form known as quartz.
Quartz is commonly found in sand,
where it often makes up most of the grains
and is the main ingredient in most type of glass.
Of course, you probably noticed that glass
isn't made of multiple tiny bits of quartz,
and for good reason.
For one thing, the edges of the rigidly formed grains
and smaller defects within the crystal structure
reflect and disperse light that hits them.
But when the quartz is heated high enough
the extra energy makes the molecules vibrate
until they break the bonds holding them together
and become a flowing liquid,
the same way that ice melts into water.
Unlike water, though, liquid silicon dioxide
does not reform into a crystal solid when it cools.
Instead, as the molecules lose energy,
they are less and less able
to move into an ordered position,
and the result is what is called an amorphous solid.
A solid material with the chaotic structure of a liquid,
which allows the molecules to freely fill in any gaps.
This makes the surface of glass uniform
on a microscopic level,
allowing light to strike it
without being scattered in different directions.
But this still doesn't explain
why light is able to pass through glass
rather than being absorbed as with most solids.
For that, we need to go all the way down
to the subatomic level.
You may know that an atom consists of a nucleus
with electrons orbiting around it,
but you may be surprised to know
that it's mostly empty space.
In fact, if an atom were the size of a sports stadium,
the nucleus would be like a single pea in the center,
while the electrons would be like grains of sand
in the outer seats.
That should leave plenty of space
for light to pass through
without hitting any of these particles.
So the real question is not
why is glass transparent,
but why aren't all materials transparent?
The answer has to do with the different energy levels
that electrons in an atom can have.
Think of these as different rows of seats
in the stadium stands.
An electron is initially assigned to sit in a certain row,
but it could jump to a better row,
if it only had the energy.
As luck would have it,
absorbing one of those light photons
passing through the atom can provide
just the energy the electron needs.
But there's a catch.
The energy from the photon
has to be the right amount
to get an electron to the next row.
Otherwise, it will just let the photon pass by,
and it just so happens that in glass,
the rows are so far apart
that a photon of visible light
can't provide enough energy for an electron
to jump between them.
Photons from ultraviolet light, on the other hand,
give just the right amount of energy,
and are absorbed,
which is why you can't get a suntan through glass.
This amazing property of being both
solid and transparent has given glass many uses
throughout the centuries.
From windows that let in light
while keeping out the elements,
to lenses that allow us to see both
the vast worlds beyond our planet,
and the tiny ones right around us.
It is hard to imagine
modern civilization without glass.
And yet for such an important material
we rarely think about glass and its impact.
It is precisely because the most important
and useful quality of glass is
being featureless and invisible
that we often forget that it's even there.

title: Why is glass transparent? - Mark Miodownik

comments.author: Scott Wheeler

comments.text:
+Scott Wheeler Colours are nothing other than specific frequences of light, 
and you might say thet they are created in our minds.

Whether a thing is transparent or not depends on the energy of the 
electromagnetic wave that hits it. Radio waves are less energetic than 
visible light, so more things are transparent to that, like brick walls. If 
you have a wave with a wavelength of several millions miles, I would guess 
that nearly anything is transparent to that, because it has extremely low 
energy.

comments.author: Irun Mon

comments.text:
+Irun Mon Why do you think it is only silicon that has this property? Any 
material that has its electrons bound to the nucleous with more energy than 
the energy of the light that hits it is transparent to that light. 
Similarly radio waves can travel through walls, because the energy of a 
radio wave is way smaller than visible light, and a wall of bricks is in 
fact transparent to that, because the electrons are tighter bound to the 
nucleous than the ray of energy that hits it.
comments.author: Fester Blats

comments.text:
So why does glass distort light, then? That's the whole point behind 
corrective lenses, telescopes, microscopes, magnifying glasses... And why 
doesn't glass appear to distort light when the glass is flat and uniform, 
instead of rounded/different thicknesses/bent?

And if you can't get a tan through glass, then what's with trucker tans

window)?﻿
comments.author: Marie Alexander

comments.text: +Grisza Plays ooooooh. That makes sense.
comments.author: Marie Alexander

comments.text:
Glass still interacts with light, it's not like they are invisible to each 
other (as funny as it sounds). Because light travels as a wave a refraction 
occurs when it changes the medium, for example from air to glass. And even 
a flat glass survace distorts light though in a more suble way - it 
slightly shifts the wave depending of the thickness of the glass.

Glass absorbs most UV frequencies but not all, some low energy UV light 
still makes it through. So the trucker from your example might indeed get a 
tan, though his exposure must have probably so long that it would have 
caused extreme sunburn if not shielded by the glass.

comments.text:
Glass doesn't block ALL UV light though only UVB not UVA which causes skin 
cancer.

UV radiation from the sun, associated with about 90 percent of all skin 
cancers, reaches the earth as long- wavelength UVA and shortwave UV B rays. 
glass effectively blocks UVB, and windshields are specially treated to 
block UVA as well, but a car’s side and rear windows allow UVA to 
penetrate.﻿

comments.author: Einsteinism :D

comments.text:
+Einsteinism :D I assume you mean becomes NOT transparent. When the 
electrons are exited by the light, they quckly fall back to their original 
orbitals, which emits photons. These photons are emitted in all directions, 
which is why you only see the surface of the object. You get a scattered 
light from all the electrons on the surface sent back towards you, and you 
cannot see through the object.

comments.text:
Great video, but some things are not clear for me such as:

In a non-transparent material, after an electron from an atom absorbed the 
necessary amount of energy from a photon to change it's 'row' does it still 
absorb photon energy? The answer must be 'Yes'
because otherwise light will just pass by it from this point on.

Or does the same electron changes 'rows' every time it absorbs energy? Does 
it oscillate between just two rows? What determines if it 'jumps' closer 
towards the nucleus or farther away from it?

Can two electrons be on the same 'row'?﻿

comments.author: Haplo Patryn

comments.text:
Correct me if I'm wrong, but don't electrons that gain energy from photons 
that proceed to jump an energy level continue to shoot out a photon and 
drop back to their original energy level, which is why you see objects? 
Because they shoot photons back after gaining the energy?
comments.author: Eiad Hamwi

comments.text:
1) Electrons can only exist on certain energy levels. It means that if a 
photon doesn't carry the right amount of energy for an electron to jump to 
a higher energy level, the photon will just go through. If it does carry 
the right amount of energy, the photon is absorbed by the electron and 
cease to exist.

2) There is not direct answer to that. It's quite complicated, it depends 
on the atom and how it is bound to other atoms because they can share 
electrons to create molecules.
However, an electron which absorbs energy jump away from the nucleus (the 
orbit is a good analogy: if you give more speed to a planet it has to be 
further away from the star to remain in a stable orbit, but think more of 
the electron as a wave oscillating around the nucleus).

3) Yes.

shouldn't objects eventually turn transparent? After the absorb the photon 
for the first time, they already have the electron on the next shell so why 
would they keep absorbing photons?﻿
comments.author: Danny Huang

comments.text:
It's exactly as the others said, when an electron goes up to the next level 
by absorving the energy produced by the photons, it will eventually go back 
to it's original energy level, since an object is always aiming to have the 
most stabile form, which is when they need the least energy. When the 
electron goes back to it's energy level it produces energy in form of a 
specific wavelength. And this is what we actually see as a color, depending 
of course on how big the wavelength is.
comments.author: dunkelchrisccd

comments.text:
It is because after the electron is being in excited state it will go down

I think it is because after absorbing the energy of a photon and getting to

remember.

a good explanation for why glass is clear.  haha
comments.author: Rob Huebschmann

comments.text:
Pretty good except the stadium analogy might confuse.  When the video 
refers to an electron jumping to a "better seat," the uninitiated will 
think that the electron is moving closer to the nucleus, when it is in fact 
moving farther away.﻿
comments.author: Juan Peralta
